body:
Hi Jovan, I'm curious, does this work with Pandas?  If the problem persists
with pandas then it would be more effective to raise the issue there.
Also, it would be useful to have a full traceback of the exception.

On Tue, Dec 17, 2019 at 9:16 PM Jovan Geraldy <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Yesterday, I am using Dask to try to working with a Local DB, I also post
> this at StackOverflow with some detailed explanation:
> https://stackoverflow.com/questions/59370582/does-dask-dataframes-not-tolerate-for-na-values-in-it-getting-valueerror-canno
>
> read_sql_table is able to read the table from my LocalDB, but The main
> issue I encounter is when I check it personally by inspecting each table
> using .head(). Here is my snippets:
>
> ddf_authorized = dd.read_sql_table("cz_transaction_authorized",
>                                    "mysql+pymysql://user_account:mysqlworld@127.0.0.1:3306/user","id")
> ddf_mobileuser = dd.read_sql_table("cz_mobile_user",
>                                    "mysql+pymysql://user_account:mysqlworld@127.0.0.1:3306/user","id")
> ddf_users = dd.read_sql_table("users",
>                               "mysql+pymysql://user_account:mysqlworld@127.0.0.1:3306/user","id")
> ddf_reader = dd.read_sql_table("reader",
>                                "mysql+pymysql://user_account:mysqlworld@127.0.0.1:3306/user","id")
> ddf_mid = dd.read_sql_table("cz_mid",
>                             "mysql+pymysql://user_account:mysqlworld@127.0.0.1:3306/user","id")
> ddf_categorymastermcc = dd.read_sql_table("category_master_mcc",
>                                           "mysql+pymysql://user_account:mysqlworld@127.0.0.1:3306/user","id")
>
> There are tables that I used .head() is giving an expected output, which
> is the first 5 rows of the table, in my case, it is only mobileuser, users,
> and categorymastermcc from above, other tables beside that will return ValueError:
> Cannot convert non-finite values (NA or inf) to integer even though I
> already get rid the NA Values and also use the tables that clear from NA,
> change the column dtype to its optimal dtype using astype(). I also tried
> to read with dd.read_csv() by exporting one of the tables into csv (which
> is reader contains 8K rows), the results is I can read the table fine and
> inspect it fine too using ,head()
>
> But since I am working also with Transacation that have 1.4M rows, (which
> in my case it is failed just to inspect the head()), it will be troublesome
> to export this kind to csv and then read it using dask.read_csv()
>
> Is there any thing I miss? or is this a bug?
>
> Thank You
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/5723?email_source=notifications&email_token=AACKZTHCJHHP5KVPZFSB2QTQZGIXBA5CNFSM4J4EWMZKYY3PNVWWK3TUL52HS4DFUVEXG43VMWVGG33NNVSW45C7NFSM4IBG7YVA>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AACKZTEGFJSS6WUGAIJOT6TQZGIXBANCNFSM4J4EWMZA>
> .
>

Hi mrocklin, thanks for the reply :)

I runned ddf_reader.head()

And this is the Exception I get...

```
Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "<ipython-input-6-9b383ccf44fb>", line 1, in <module>
    ddf_reader.head()

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\dataframe\core.py", line 950, in head
    return self._head(n=n, npartitions=npartitions, compute=compute, safe=True)

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\dataframe\core.py", line 983, in _head
    result = result.compute()

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\base.py", line 165, in compute
    (result,) = compute(self, traverse=False, **kwargs)

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\base.py", line 436, in compute
    results = schedule(dsk, keys, **kwargs)

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\threaded.py", line 81, in get
    **kwargs

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\local.py", line 486, in get_async
    raise_exception(exc, tb)

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\local.py", line 316, in reraise
    raise exc

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\local.py", line 222, in execute_task
    result = _execute_task(task, data)

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\core.py", line 118, in _execute_task
    args2 = [_execute_task(a, cache) for a in args]

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\core.py", line 118, in <listcomp>
    args2 = [_execute_task(a, cache) for a in args]

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\core.py", line 118, in _execute_task
    args2 = [_execute_task(a, cache) for a in args]

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\core.py", line 118, in <listcomp>
    args2 = [_execute_task(a, cache) for a in args]

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\core.py", line 118, in _execute_task
    args2 = [_execute_task(a, cache) for a in args]

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\core.py", line 118, in <listcomp>
    args2 = [_execute_task(a, cache) for a in args]

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\core.py", line 119, in _execute_task
    return func(*args2)

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\utils.py", line 29, in apply
    return func(*args, **kwargs)

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\dask\dataframe\io\sql.py", line 210, in _read_sql_chunk
    return df.astype(meta.dtypes.to_dict(), copy=False)

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\generic.py", line 5866, in astype
    dtype=dtype[col_name], copy=copy, errors=errors, **kwargs

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\generic.py", line 5883, in astype
    dtype=dtype, copy=copy, errors=errors, **kwargs

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\internals\managers.py", line 581, in astype
    return self.apply("astype", dtype=dtype, **kwargs)

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\internals\managers.py", line 438, in apply
    applied = getattr(b, f)(**kwargs)

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\internals\blocks.py", line 557, in astype
    return self._astype(dtype, copy=copy, errors=errors, values=values, **kwargs)

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\internals\blocks.py", line 641, in _astype
    values = astype_nansafe(vals1d, dtype, copy=True, **kwargs)

  File "c:\users\user\appdata\local\programs\python\python37\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\dtypes\cast.py", line 700, in astype_nansafe
    "Cannot convert non-finite values (NA or inf) to " "integer"

ValueError: Cannot convert non-finite values (NA or inf) to integer
```
to test the reader table (if wanted), the reader table I converted to csv, are Included in the stackoverflow.. is is the table which I used to inspect the head()

And also I test it in Pandas too. This works in Pandas..

x = pd.read_sql_table("reader", "mysql+pymysql://user_account:mysqlworld@127.0.0.1:3306/user")

x.head()
Out[6]: 
   id      devicetype_fk  version  ... device_type merchant          last_ksn_mag
0   1  INGENICO_ICMP_122        1  ...        None     None                  None
1   2  INGENICO_ICMP_122       47  ...        None     None  4101202122340000002F
2   3  INGENICO_ICMP_122        1  ...        None     None                  None
3   4  INGENICO_ICMP_122      290  ...        None     None                  None
4   5  INGENICO_ICMP_122      107  ...        None     None                  None

[5 rows x 18 columns]

@Vanderser what are the dtypes on `ddf_reader`, and what are the types of the columns on the table?

That error message indicates an issue with trying to convert a float column to ints, which usually indicates a type inference problem. You might pass `meta=` to the `read_sql_table` with the correct dtypes. `read_csv` has a nice error message for this case.

actually for ddf_reader, I just subset it to these 3 important columns only, 

```
ddf_reader = ddf_reader.reset_index()
ddf_reader = ddf_reader[["id","devicetype_fk","serial_number"]]
ddf_reader = ddf_reader.rename(columns={"id":"reader_id"})

ddf_reader.columns.values
Out[18]: array(['reader_id', 'devicetype_fk', 'serial_number'], dtype=object)

ddf_reader["reader_id"].dtype
Out[19]: dtype('int64')

ddf_reader["devicetype_fk"].dtype
Out[20]: dtype('O')

ddf_reader["serial_number"].dtype
Out[21]: dtype('O')
```
so to put it straight.. my ddf_reader didn;t have the float columns.. but even with this, this still triggered the `ValueError: Cannot convert non-finite values (NA or inf) to integer`

The issue is (maybe) that `reader_id` is expecting integers by finds
missing values (floats), though it's hard to say for sure.without a minimal
example. Did you provide the types from the database? Is ID nullable?

What types do you get when you read with pandas?


On Wed, Dec 18, 2019 at 7:26 AM Jovan Geraldy <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

@TomAugspurger here is the ddf_reader I converted for working example.. http://www.sharecsv.com/s/147ba0bb507bb6dcc14a3a6c91af4eef/reader_table.csv this is the table itself converted, I was sure there wasn't any null values in reader_id

This is the defined types from Database
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40754909/71139152-ee07e400-223f-11ea-8560-e796b3edaa70.png)

Pandas type is the same with Dask..

```
x = pd.read_sql_table("reader", "mysql+pymysql://user_account:mysqlworld@127.0.0.1:3306/user")
x.rename(columns={"id":"reader_id"}, inplace=True)

x["reader_id"].dtype
Out[4]: dtype('int64')

x["serial_number"].dtype
Out[5]: dtype('O')

x["devicetype_fk"].dtype
Out[6]: dtype('O')
```
Hard to say what's going on. I'd recommend trying to reduce things to the smallest possible example (size, columns, dtypes) that exhibits the issue to understand where things are going wrong.
@Vanderser were you able to build a smaller example ?

Hi All, its been for 4 Months since my last reports, and for now the last example doesn't exist anymore..  until now I am not sure how to fix this problem... but I have this simplified new example according the issues, with this snippets:

```
import pandas as pd
import pymysql
import dask.dataframe as dd

x = pd.read_sql_table("cz_merchant", "mysql+pymysql://dba.jovan:dbminingczdsjovan@127.0.0.1:33062/czmining_mart_payment",index_col = "id")
y = dd.read_sql_table("cz_merchant", "mysql+pymysql://dba.jovan:dbminingczdsjovan@127.0.0.1:33062/czmining_mart_payment",index_col = "id")
```
above I used Pandas and Dask both to read the same table at my DB.. then i tried to run this info on both: (from the looks of it, It sure that there is Different column types with Pandas and Dask methods)

```
x.info()
<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
Int64Index: 18309 entries, 1 to 18956
Columns: 106 entries, version to pic_contact_email
dtypes: datetime64[ns](7), float64(6), int64(6), object(87)
memory usage: 14.9+ MB

y.info()
<class 'dask.dataframe.core.DataFrame'>
Columns: 106 entries, version to pic_contact_email
dtypes: datetime64[ns](4), object(91), float64(2), int64(9)
```

and finally error came back again when I use the verbose=True parameter

